heading: drug calms pitter-pattering hearts
subheading: a drug used to treat irregular heartbeat proves to be highly effective in a recent study. it offers options other than the standard electrical shock treatment.
author: reuters
text: pharmacia & upjohn inc. said all 50 of the atrial fibrillation patients treated with the company's corvert injection, whether it was administered alone or combined with an electrical shock, were restored to normal heart rhythm. this compared to 36 of 50 patients treated with electrical shock alone, in a 100-patient study. as reported 17 april 1996, the drug, which treats atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter, received food and drug administration approval in december 1995.in a press release wednesday, pharmacia & upjohn said that in the 14 patients for whom electrical shock alone failed, normal heart rhythm was restored when electrical shock was attempted again after administration of corvert.the company also said treatment with corvert before electrical shock reduced the required intensity of the shock by 30 percent.read ongoing med-tech coverage - - - - - -corvert caused no deaths or long-term complications in the study.pharmacia & upjohn said corvert, like other antiarrhythmic agents, carries the risk of sustained polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, or pvt, which is an arrhythmia of the ventricles.of the 64 patients receiving corvert, two developed sustained pvt within 15 minutes after infusion. in both cases, the arrhythmia resolved with treatment.patients with a heart condition that predisposed them to the risk of pvt were excluded from the study.corvert is marketed in 11 countries.copyright
